title: Does Mitt Romney need 'Obamacare'?
content:
Romney is one Republican who might be sorry if the court strikes down the law . | REUTERS Does Romney need 'Obamacare ' ?
Republicans are cheerleading for the Supreme Court to strike down President Barack Obama ’ s health care law .
But there ’ s one Republican who might be sorry : Mitt Romney .
There 's fear in some GOP circles that if the court wipes the Affordable Care Act off the books Romney will lose a rallying point for the movement conservatives he has been struggling to inspire .
“ Clearly , the Supreme Court overturning Obamacare is the best thing for the country , but it ’ s an open question what ’ s better for November ’ s election , ” Rep. Patrick McHenry ( R-N.C. ) said . If the law is upheld , he said , “ it might drive our people out to the polls . ”
As the justices get ready to rule this month , political pros on both sides are wrestling with how best to position their candidates in the aftermath of the decision . In closed-door meetings last week , House Republican leaders started laying the groundwork for what they hope will be a unified GOP response no matter what the outcome .
The White House , which has both the president ’ s political standing and his signature achievement at risk , has to root for the court to uphold the law in its entirety . But Republicans say they ’ ve been giving a lot of consideration lately to the possibility that a mortal blow to the law could agitate Obama ’ s base and temper the urgency of their own activists .
“ Obamacare is the one permanent and potentially irreversible [ effect ] that Obama will have on the country , and if it is overturned , it makes the election , by default , less important , ” a conservative operative intimately involved in the campaign who has reviewed extensive polling and focus group research on the topic told ███ earlier this week . “ If the court overturns it , 10 million conservative activists suddenly breathe a great sigh of relief , and may not be quite as intensely active . ”
It 's easy to see why Republicans might think the law surviving is good for them : A CBS/New York Times poll released Thursday found that more than two-thirds of respondents believe it should be struck down in whole or in part . It would also give Romney — the author of a state-level health care law similar to the federal one — a much clearer contrast with Obama on health care . Obama wrote the Affordable Care Act ; Romney is campaigning to repeal it .
`` As president , I will work from my first day in office to dismantle Barack Obama ’ s federal health care takeover and replace it with real reform that strengthens our health care system and puts patients first , '' Romney said Thursday .
Republicans on Capitol Hill buzzed this week about the various scenarios and how they could affect the November election , and several lawmakers said they 've been kicking around the question of what 's best for them politically with staff and colleagues .
“ I could argue it both ways , and I have argued it both ways , ” Rep. Patrick Tiberi ( R-Ohio ) told ███ . “ I could see the president , if the mandate is thrown out , using it to rev up his troops . ”

But there’s one Republican who might be sorry: Mitt Romney.

There's fear in some GOP circles that if the court wipes the Affordable Care Act off the books Romney will lose a rallying point for the movement conservatives he has been struggling to inspire.

“Clearly, the Supreme Court overturning Obamacare is the best thing for the country, but it’s an open question what’s better for November’s election,” Rep. Patrick McHenry (R-N.C.) said. If the law is upheld, he said, “it might drive our people out to the polls.”

( Also on POLITICO: Romney: 'Forward' slogan is 'absurd')

As the justices get ready to rule this month, political pros on both sides are wrestling with how best to position their candidates in the aftermath of the decision. In closed-door meetings last week, House Republican leaders started laying the groundwork for what they hope will be a unified GOP response no matter what the outcome.

The White House, which has both the president’s political standing and his signature achievement at risk, has to root for the court to uphold the law in its entirety. But Republicans say they’ve been giving a lot of consideration lately to the possibility that a mortal blow to the law could agitate Obama’s base and temper the urgency of their own activists.

“Obamacare is the one permanent and potentially irreversible [effect] that Obama will have on the country, and if it is overturned, it makes the election, by default, less important,” a conservative operative intimately involved in the campaign who has reviewed extensive polling and focus group research on the topic told POLITICO earlier this week. “If the court overturns it, 10 million conservative activists suddenly breathe a great sigh of relief, and may not be quite as intensely active.”

It's easy to see why Republicans might think the law surviving is good for them: A CBS/New York Times poll released Thursday found that more than two-thirds of respondents believe it should be struck down in whole or in part. It would also give Romney — the author of a state-level health care law similar to the federal one — a much clearer contrast with Obama on health care. Obama wrote the Affordable Care Act; Romney is campaigning to repeal it.

"As president, I will work from my first day in office to dismantle Barack Obama’s federal health care takeover and replace it with real reform that strengthens our health care system and puts patients first," Romney said Thursday.

Republicans on Capitol Hill buzzed this week about the various scenarios and how they could affect the November election, and several lawmakers said they've been kicking around the question of what's best for them politically with staff and colleagues.

“I could argue it both ways, and I have argued it both ways,” Rep. Patrick Tiberi (R-Ohio) told POLITICO. “I could see the president, if the mandate is thrown out, using it to rev up his troops.”
